content: A change in fuel tank regulations for 1970 forced those manufacturers keen to continue competing in Formula 2 to substantially modify their existing cars in order to accommodate new aircraft-style rubber bag fuel tanks. Further modifications were made to the suspension, principally by the inclusion of new destruction-tested lower wishbones, and the 59’s snub-nose was replaced by a low-line wedge with an underslung intake feeding air through the radiator. content: The light-alloy monocoque design, with its wedge nose and twin wings, reminded some observers of a hammerhead shark. Conceived by Colin Chapman and executed by Maurice Philippe, it proved to be perhaps the lightest car in Formula 1. The car's weight equalled the minimum permitted level of 530 kg, including fluids. Every aspect of the car evinced new and radical thinking. In appearance, its most visibly striking features were the side-mounted radiators, which allowed the car's designers to find an aerodynamically more efficient profile than previous cars. The gearbox from Hewland and the engine, Cosworth's 3-litre DFV, remained open to the elements. However, elsewhere, attention to aerodynamics was impeccable with flush rivets on external planes, a slim nose profile, and carefully contoured rear sections to give the best possible penetration and airflow. Throughout its five-year life, the car was most closely associated with sponsor John Player & Son, initially racing in red. Launched to the assembled press at Hethel on 6th April 1970, the Lotus Type 72, with no fewer than twenty Grand Prix victories to its name over the course of five years, established itself as one of the truly great Grand Prix cars. Racing in the red, launched to the assembled press at Hethel on 6th April 1970, the Lotus Type 72 established itself as one of the truly great Grand Prix cars. Indeed, it could arguably claim to be the most outstanding Formula 1 car of its decade, if not of all time. Initially adorned in the white and gold of Gold Leaf Team Lotus, it soon adopted the soon-to-be world-famous black and gold livery as the very first John Player Special. The Type 72 made its debut at the 1970 Spanish Grand Prix but failed to find much success until Rindt took pole position in practice at Zandvoort. With Rindt going on to win the race itself, as well as the French, German, and British rounds in 72/R2 (Rindt also won the Monaco GP that year after reverting back to the trusty Type 49), he took the driver's title, with Team Lotus also taking the constructors' championship. Throughout the season, numerous small modifications were made, most noticeably the addition of an airbox over the injection system, an innovation soon adopted by several rival teams.

The 1970 season was overshadowed by the tragic loss of Rindt during official practice at Monza. Despite there being three races left in the season, his points total of 45 could only be surpassed by one driver, Jacky Ickx in the Ferrari. Emerson Fittipaldi was thrust into the limelight as team leader to defend Rindt's position at the top of the table. After the team missed the Canadian Grand Prix, Fittipaldi came of age at the United States Grand Prix at Watkins Glen. On race day, he drove a steady race, benefiting from the retirements of others to score his first Grand Prix win and ensure that Jochen Rindt became the sport's first and only posthumous World Champion. For the 1971 season, the Type 72 remained almost unchanged, save for a few minor modifications. The Type 72 was a milestone car in Formula 1 history.

content: 1973 Based around a striking but actually quite simple sheet aluminium alloy monocoque with GRP bodywork, the racing Type 74 was the work of Ralph Bellamy. Its most distinguishing feature at the car's launch was a wide, though not quite full-width, shovel-shaped nose section. The fabricated double wishbone front suspension operated inboard torsion bars and dampers, while at the rear, there was a more conventional coil spring/damper set up. The disc brakes were inboard at all four corners, and the side-mounted radiators for oil and water were fitted almost flush to the sides of the monocoque. Power came from the Lotus Type 906 alloy block, a twin overhead camshaft unit of 1,973cc and, some said, a derivation of its production engine, itself based on the cast iron General Motors/Vauxhall Victor unit that had already been extensively modified by Novamotor. By Formula 2 standards, it was a fairly large power pack, also a somewhat uncompetitive one, by the time several early reliability problems had been dealt with. Figures for its original power output are not available, but by the time early problems were resolved and the car was considered ready for competition, a rating of around 275bhp seems plausible.

So it was that he decided to incorporate into the new Type 92 a computer-controlled 'active' suspension system that Team Lotus had had under development for so long. This system, while comparatively heavy with around 20 kilograms of hardware and requiring an additional 1.5 gallons of hydraulic fluid, was certainly clever. Designed and developed in partnership with Britain's Cranfield College of Aeronautics, it featured hydraulic rams on all four corners which were powered by a small centrally-located engine-driven pump. These rams effectively replaced the springs, anti-roll bars, and dampers and were controlled from a central processing unit (CPU) which received telemetric data from a battery of accelerometers as well as load sensors and transducers mounted on each ram. By analyzing the electronic input from these sensors, the CPU was able to build a 'picture' of the vehicle's movements and attitudes. Receiving signals back from the CPU, the suspension rams were then able to react almost instantaneously by extending or shortening the suspension travel to optimize the chassis attitude and control.
